poem:
**Mission Unaccomplished**

In flickering dreamscapes—  
a reel not quite spooled—  
heroes chase specters  
through the scissor's snip,  
illusions slipping  
like shadows in dawn fog.

Once, the screen's glow,  
a hymn of daring;  
now, echoes ricochet  
in an empty theater,  
plotlines fracturing  
under years of strain.  

Oh, stealthy sabotage of  
expectation's threads!  
Unraveled in the reels' twilight.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Impossibly frustrating: why Mission: Impossible 8 was a major letdown If the title is sincere, and this really is the final reckoning, then it’s been a franchise of two halves. Mission: Impossible diehards tend to underrate the first half (which ran from Brian De Palma’s brisk 1996 original to 2011’s fun Ghost Protocol) as much as they overrate the second (which launched with 2015’s Rogue Nation). Yet the rumbles and grumbles emanating from public screenings". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Impossibly frustrating: why Mission: Impossible 8 was a major letdown If the title is sincere, and this really is the final reckoning, then it’s been a franchise of two halves.
